summary: Email correspondence between legal staff regarding Ghislaine Maxwell's motions in limine in her criminal case (U.S. v. Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330). The email chain includes forwarding of defense motions and discussion of access to shared case files.

persons.name: Nicole Simmons
persons.context: Sent the motions in limine on behalf of Jeffrey Pagliuca to Judge Nathan's chambers.

persons.name: Nathan
persons.context: Addressed as 'Judge Nathan' in the email, recipient of the motions in limine.

persons.name: Jeffrey Pagliuca
persons.context: Requested that Nicole Simmons send Ghislaine Maxwell's motions in limine to the court.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Copied on the email regarding the motions in limine.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Subject of the criminal case (U.S. v. Maxwell) and whose defense team filed 13 motions in limine.

connections.description: Pagliuca is part of Maxwell's defense team, as he requested the filing of her motions in limine.
Simmons acted at Pagliuca's request to send legal documents to the court.
Both were involved in the email correspondence regarding Maxwell's legal filings.

events.title: Filing of Maxwell's Motions in Limine
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team filed 13 motions in limine in her criminal case.

locations: NYS (likely New York Southern District court)
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense filed 13 motions in limine in her criminal case (U.S. v. Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330).
The motions were transmitted via email from Nicole Simmons of Haddon, Morgan and Foreman P.C. to Judge Nathan's chambers.
The email chain indicates use of a shared drive for case documents (Wisa.doj.gov cloud) related to the Epstein/Maxwell case.
Multiple legal personnel (Jeffrey Pagliuca, Laura Menninger) were involved in the filing process.
The correspondence is dated October 2021, during the pre-trial phase of Maxwell's prosecution.
